title: Rights fight: Poles protest restrictive abortion limits
description: Demonstrations sprung up in numerous Polish cities on Saturday in protest of restricting abortion rights.
text_headers:
Abortion-rights protesters take to the streets…

			Abortion-rights protesters take to the streets of major Polish cities		

Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on X (Opens in new window)Czarek Sokolowski/AP PhotoPolice use tear gas against opposition lawmaker, Barbara Nowacka, as protesters block a major thoroughfare in Warsaw on Saturday.Czarek Sokolowski/AP PhotoPolice intervene after protesters block a major thoroughfare in Warsaw, Poland, on Saturday.Show Caption of ExpandBy Storm GiffordPUBLISHED: November 28, 2020 at 6:24 p.m. | UPDATED: November 29, 2020 at 1:18 a.m.Abortion-rights activists in Poland were protesting yet again on Saturday.
For the sixth consecutive week in the central European nation, demonstrators marched in Warsaw, Krakow and Gdansk, demanding an easing of restrictive abortion laws as well as criticizing law enforcement officials of using excessive force and shooting pepper spray at peaceful protesters, reported The Associated Press on Saturday.
“We have a right to protest!” chanted demonstrators.
Warsaw cops blocked protesters from marching through the capital city’s streets, erecting barricades which the demonstrators sought to bypass.

A mother with two teen girls held a sign in Warsaw which read, “I am here for my daughters.”

Police intervene after protesters block a major thoroughfare in Warsaw, Poland, on Saturday.
Officers claimed that the protest was illegal due to being an unregistered event and in violation of COVID-19 social-distancing restrictions. 


But Warsaw demonstrators who amassed on a major street to impede traffic, shouted, “We are sorry for the inconvenience, we have a government to overthrow!”
Cops deployed tear gas on Barbara Nowacka, a lawmaker intervening “in defense of peacefully protesting women,” claimed party leader Borys Budka. 


Many protesters toted signs with a silhouette image of a suffragette with a red lightning bolt and the words “Strajk Kobiet” — Women’s Strike.
Women’s rights activists have called on authorities to formally change the name of a downtown Warsaw square to Women’s Rights Roundabout.
“Facing a near total ban on abortion, people in Poland have mobilized impressively,” explained Nils Mulzieks, the European director at Amnesty International, earlier this month. “However, not content with violating their reproductive rights, authorities have used this opportunity to also crack down on their right to peacefully protest.”

Police use tear gas against opposition lawmaker, Barbara Nowacka, as protesters block a major thoroughfare in Warsaw on Saturday.
Protests began on Oct. 22, the same day the Polish constitutional court ruled on an abortion ban of fetuses with congenital defects, even when the fetus is expected to die.
Poland’s 1993 abortion law allowed the procedure only in cases of fetal defects, incest, rape or risk to a mother’s health.
